titlestmt.titleproper: History of the Written Word: Pages from the Past, 2400 BCE-1920 CE
History of the Written Word: Pages from the Past, 2400 BCE-1920 CE Z4 .H58
titlestmt.subtitle: Collection of History of the Written Word: Pages from the Past, 2400 BCE-1920 CE, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Ava Dickerson

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-02-18 22:33:51 -0500.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: History of the Written Word: Pages from the Past
did.abstract: The History of the Written Word: Pages from the Past, 2400 BCE-1920 CE, consist of a collection of original leaves from rare books and manuscripts in limited portfolio sets.
did.langmaterial: Egyptian (Ancient) , Sumerian , Portuguese , Latin , Hebrew , Arabic , Greek, Ancient (to 1453) , German , English , Spanish; Castilian , French , Dutch; Flemish , Italian , Greek, Modern (1453-) , Persian .

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Society of Foliophiles formed in the early 1920's to discuss special collections and book collecting. In an attempt to make collecting more financially attainable, the Society began to collect manuscript leaves and fragments and assemble them into thematic portfolios for sale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The set includes examples of early printed leaves, manuscript leaves, as well as a Babylonian clay tablet and cylinder seal, Egyptian papyri, etc. Each leaf is mounted on a black sheet of heavy paper (51 x 33 cm.). Leaves are housed in four black leather, drop-front clamshell cases.

"This is collection no. ... in Portfolio Set I: History of the Written Word: Only 20 numbered sets have been issued. When this edition is completed, it obviously ends this series for all time"--limitation leaf (laid-in volume 1).
Lilly Library's set numbered 14 and signed by Foliophiles director, Alfred Stites, on the limitation leaf Lilly Library's copy lacking the prospectus with descriptive table of contents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged roughly chronologically.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], History of the Written Word: Pages from the Past, Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.

did.unittitle: Title sheet with wax stamp and limitation statement
Babylonian clay tablet with cuneiform characters
Babylonian cylinder seal with Sumerian inscription; accompanied by a portion of clay which shows the inscription in relief
Egyptian scarab with hieroglyphics. Accompanied by a portion of clay which shows sign of the scarab in relief
Fragment of an Egyptian papyrus, Book of the Dead
Leaf from a manuscript Koran, probably Egyptian in origin
Vellum leaf, Officium Beate Marie Virginis, by an Italian scribe
Leaf from Los Virtuosos Varones, a Portuguese manuscript on the nobility of the Portuguese aristocracy
Leaf (S4) from Infortiatum de Tortis, a large, very beautiful law book printed by Baptista de Tortis in Venice, type is bold gothic
Leaf from a rare breviary (called "Portiforium," or handbook) adapted to the distinctive service of Salisbury Cathedral. Printed in London by John Kyngston and Henry Sutton

Leaf from a Hebrew Bible. The books of the Major Prophets, Joshua, Judges, Samuel and Kings, printed in Hebrew by Robert Estienne (or Stephanus), son and successor of the more famous Henri Estienne, at Paris
Fragment from an Arabic papyrus
Fragment from a Greek papyrus
Leaf from Fascuculus Mirre, Delft, Roelant Bollaert
Vellum leaf from the Dutch Book of Hours
did.unitdate: written in the middle of the 15th century

did.unittitle: Vellum manuscript leaf from a German religious work, written in an upright, careful gothic German
Vellum leaf (Fi) from a printed Book of Hours, probably French in origin (with woodblock border and hand-painted blue, red and gold initial letters)
Leaf from Vocabularius Praedicantium sire Variloguus, printed in Strassburg by Georg Hasner
Leaf from the Nüremberg Chronicle, printed by Anton Koberger
Leaf from De Imitatione Christi of Thomas A Kempis, printed by Caspar Hochfeder at Nüremberg
Leaf (I) from In Psalterium Expositio, by Cassiodorus
Leaf from the Chronicarum Supplementum of Jacobus Philippus Bergomensis (Foresti), an Augustinian friar; printed by Bernadinus de Benaliis, at Venice
Leaf (C4) from the Opus Trivium, by Jean (John) Bromyard, an English theologian. Printed by Nicolas Wolff at Lyons
Leaf (2[rum]3) from A Digest of Civil Law, by Andrea Torresano of Asolo
Leaf from The Propositions of Aristotle, a book of excerpts in Latin from the writings of Aristotle. Printed in Venice by Joannes and Gregorius de Gregoriis
Leaf (O2) from Gemma Vocabulorum, printed in Deventer by R. Pafraet
Leaf (ii2) from a Latin version of the Bible, printed in Venice by Hieronymus de Paganini
Leaf (FF4) from the first illustrated edition of Horace, printed by John Gruninger in Strassburg
Leaf (e2) from Stultefera Navis, the Latin version of the famous satirical German poem, Das Narrenschiff, or Ship of Fools, by Sebastian Brant; printed by Bergman von Olpe at Basle
Leaf from Biblia Latina, an incunable work printed in Venice by Reynsburch and Novimagio

Leaf (p. 39) from Fasciculus Temporum, an early outline of history from the creation of the world to about 1480, by Werner Rollewinck; this leaf is from the 5th edition of Erhard Ratdolt, which he brought out in Venice
Leaf from Postilla Super Psalterium, Hugo de Sancto Caro; printed in Nüremberg by Anthoni Koberger
Leaf (r3) from Arbor Scientiae, by Raimond Lull; Barcelona. Includes some ms notes
Leaf (d2) from the Chronicon of Sigebert of Gembloux; printed by Henri Estienne (Henry Stephanus) at Paris
Leaf (L) from Aeneis Vergiliana, printed by Jacobus Sacon of Lyons
Leaf from the Commentaries on Boetius, printed by Zanotus de Castelliono for Giangiacomo de Legnano and Brothers, booksellers, at Milan
Leaf from a German manuscript-an interesting anti-Catholic theological diatribe signed by five Protestant pastors
Leaf (at top right: Fol. X) from the fourth and last edition of the mysterious Matthew's Bible, printed by Nicholas Hyll at London
Another leaf (at top of page: The Epistle) from the fourth and last edition of the mysterious Matthew's Bible, printed by Nicholas Hyll at London
Leaf (N2) from Hortus Sanitatis, this particular version by Johann von Cube of Frankfort being a compilation of two others bearing the same title and published at Mainz
Leaf (O2) from Fasciculus Mirre, Delft, Roelant Bollaert
Leaf (F) from Dante's Divine Comedy, with the commentary of Christoforo Landino, printed by Jacob del Burgofranco of Pavia for Lucantonio Giunta, at Venice
Leaf from Biblia Picturis Illustrata; printed in Paris by Pierre Regnault
Leaf (Z3) from a famous theological treatise of the 16th century, being the Text of the Opinions of Master Pietrus Lombardus; printed by Jean Moylin at Lyons
Leaf (P4) from The Twelve Books of the Orations of Quintilian; printed by Pierre Vidoue and published by Jean Petit at Paris
Leaf (C3) from The Twelve Books of the Orations of Quintilian; printed by Pierre Vidoue and published by Jean Petit at Paris
Leaf (C4) from Postille Majores cum Questionibus, by Pierre Balli; printed by him at Lyons
Leaf from The Commentaries of Bartolus de Saxoferrato on the first and second parts of the new Digest of Laws with supplemental notes by other scholars. Published at Lyons by Jacob Saccon
Leaf (S2) from Nova Legenda Angliae, from the press of Wynkyn de Worde, printed at "the Flete Strete," London
Leaf (p. 144) from a collection of minor classical authors; printed by Aldus Manutius and Andrea Torresano at Venice
Leaf (S3) from Las Quatorze Decadas de Tito Livio; printed at Saragossa by George Coci
Leaf (p. 323) from Sebastian Munster's Cosmographia Universalis; printed by Heinrich Petri at Basle
Another leaf from the Commentaries on Boetius, printed by Zanotus de Castelliono for Giangiacomo de Legnano and Brothers, booksellers, at Milan
Leaf (A4) from the Saturnalia of Macrobius, by Joannes Rivius; printed by Agostino de Zanni de Portesio for Lucantonio Giunta at Venice
Leaf from The Cornucopia of Nicholas Perottus; printed at Venice, Aldine press
Leaf (E2) from Tabulae Eclypsium; printed by Johannes Winterburger at Vienna
Leaf (Eee, p. 877) from Works of Josephus, Basle, Jerome Froben
Leaf (FF3, p. 338) from Historia de Gentibus Septentrionalibus, by Olaus Magnus, Archbishop of Upsala; this leaf is from the original Latin edition, published at Rome
Leaf (Ee.v., p. 802) from a Latin version of the Bible, printed by the heirs of Carola Guillard, relict of Claude Chevallon, at Paris
Another leaf (PP5, p. 914) from Sebastian Munster's Cosmographia Universalis; printed by Heinrich Petri at Basle
Leaf (D1) from An English Book of Laws, printed by Rycharde Jugge and John Cawood, at London
Leaf (Q2, p. 230) from The History of His Own Times, by Paulus Jovius, Bishop of Nocera, printed by Michael Vascosanus at Paris

Leaf (C, p. 33) from "Commentariorum in Ordinationes Regias Castellae," a Spanish law book containing a compilation of the ordinances of Castile; printed in the shop of Dominicus à Portonariis at the expense of Vincentius à Portonariis, Salamanca
Leaf (p. 153) from the so-called "Liber Sextus" of Pope Boniface VIII; this leaf is from the edition printed at Venice
Leaf (N2, p. xcv) from a book of services for the Christmas, Holy Week, &c., with musical accompaniment, published by Matthias Gastius at Salamanca
Leaf (p. 157) from Ovid's "Metamorphoses," printed by Joan. Gryphius in Venice
Leaf (p. 86) from a work on Euclid by Nicholas Tartalea; the author's last, revised edition, printed by Curtio Troiano in Venice
Leaf (p. 83) from "A Catholike and Ecclesiasticall Exposition of the Holy Gospell after S. John," translated by Thomas Timme. Printed in London, by Thomas Marshe
Leaf (p. 95) from Plutarch's "Lives of the Noble Grecians and Romanes," translated, out of the French version of Bishop Amyot, by Sir Thomas North; printed by Thomas Vautrollier at London
Leaf from a Roman missal, issued in accordance with the decrees of the famous Council of Trent, and printed by the heirs of Lucantonio di Giunta at Venice
Leaf (Bb3) from the life of Jesus Christ, translated into Dutch from the Latin of Ludolphus of Saxony, a Carthusian monk, and printed by Peter van Ghelen at Antwerp
Leaf from a French liturgical ms
Leaf from a breviary (includes some ms notes)
Leaf (L2, p. 58) from Polybius, his complete history, a work by the author Polybius, and printed at Haganau by printer Johannem Secerium
Leaf (Ooo3) from De Aquitilibus, Historiae Animalium, by Gessner, printed at Zurich by Fraschover
Leaf (K4, p. 151) from the first edition of the first Latin Bible to be printed in England, the Biblia Sacra; printed by Henry Middleton
Leaf (p. 70-71) from History of Religious Orders of the early 1600's. Printed by Menier in Paris, being the second edition
Leaf (p. 128) from "A Guide to Tongues," by John Minsheu. Printed at the charges of the author for John Browne, Bookseller, London
Leaf (p. 1110) from The Herball of John Gerard; printed by Thomas Johnson in London
Leaf (p. 7) from A Display of Heraldrie, by John Guillim, printed at London by Thomas Cotes for Jacob Blome
Leaf Nnn1 from Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy, printed at Oxford, by John Lichfield
Leaf (p. 311) from an Italian manuscript, by Theodorus Amydenius, a lawyer in the Roman Curia
did.unitdate: written about the middle of the 17th century

did.unittitle: Leaf (p. 165?) from a Spanish antiphonary, typical of the Catholic choir books of that period, particularly in Spain
Leaf from an Italian manuscript, by "Perlone Zipoli," a transparent anagram under which Lorenzo Lippi, the well-known painter, chose to hide his authorship
Leaf (p. 59) from the Workes of Benjamin Jonson, printed by Richard Bishop at London
Leaf (N4) from a book of rituals of the Anglican Church, printed at London by Robert Barker
Leaf from the New World of Words, collected and published by Edward Phillips and printed by W.R. for Robert Harford at London
Leaf (p. 27) from the Holy Bible, Or "Biblia Sacra" Vulgate Editionis, edited by Popes Sextus V and Clemens VIII; printed in Venice by Pezzana
Leaf (p. 784) from Numisatum Antiquorum, an illustrated work by Ezechiel Spanhemius, printed by Daniel Elsiver at Amsterdam
Leaf (p. 493) from the Iconologia of Cesare Ripa of Perugia, with amplifications by Giovanni Zaratino Castellini, printed by Niccolo Pezzana at Venice
Leaf (p. 86) from Estatutos Generales de Barcelona, a book of religious statutes, brought out in Mexico, by Pedro Ocharte
Leaf (p. 598) from Portraits et Vies des Hommes Illustres, par André Thevet; from the press of Kervert and Chaudiére, Paris
Leaf (p. [192]) from Martin Luther's German translation of the Bible, published by the heirs of Hans Krafft at Wittenberg
Leaf (p. 789) from the sermons of John Calvin, translated from the French by Arthur Golding; printed by Henry Middleton for George Bishop, London
Leaf from the King James Bible; printed by Robert Barker, London
Leaf (S2) from a New Testament in Greek, issued by the house of Elzevir at Amsterdam
Leaf (p. 256) from the New Testament in English printed by Daniel Vervliet at Antwerp
Leaf (Aij1) from Anatome Corporis Humani, by Joanne Valverdo, an Italian translation from the author's original manual in Spanish; from the Giunta Press and published at Venice
Leaf (p. 353/354) from the "Justinian Code," Ex Officina Vignoniana in St. Gervais, near Paris
Leaf I1 from The Four Bookes of Husbandry, collected by Conrad Heresbach and translated by Barnaby Googe. "Imprinted at London for Thomas Wight, dwelling in Paules Churchyarde, Anno Domini, 1596"
Leaf (C3) from "A Guide to Tongues," by John Minsheu. Printed at the charges of the author for John Browne, Bookseller, London
Leaf (C2) from the first King James Bible in a popular edition. Printed and published by Robert Barker, the King's printer, London
Leaf (R3) from Book of European Travels, written by George Sandys, the well-known translator of Ovid in London
Leaf (K1) from Hieroglyphica, by the Reverend Archibald Simson, a Scottish preacher, and was brought out at Edinburgh by Thomas Finlason, printer to His Majesty
Leaf (p. 98) from the Hebrew Pentateuch, printed in four volumes by Pierre de la Roviere in Geneva

Leaf (Gg3) from Willliam Camden's "Annalles of Elizabeth," or rather from Darcie's translation from a French translation of Camden's original work, which was written in Latin. Printed for Benjamin Fisher in London
Leaf (p. 83) from an Irish law book, containing the Statutes of Ireland from the reign of King Edward up to and including part of that of James I. Printed by the Society of Stationers at Dublin

Leaf (p. 285) from a miniature Elzevir, viz., the much-prized volume on France in the "Republic Series," the little pocket library of travel books that have acquired a fame in inverse ratio to their size. Printed in Leyden
Leaf from an illuminated Persian ms
Leaf (Qq2) from the Vulgate edition of the Bible printed at the celebrated Plantin Press in Antwerp
Leaf from Flora Londinensis, compiled and written by William Curtis, from the 1st edition, and printed in London
Leaf X2 from The Lessons of the Protestant Episcopal Church, compiled by Andrew Fowler and published by Blauvelt, New Brunswick, New Jersey
Leaf (p. 129) from The Doctrines and Discipline of the Methodist Episocopal [sic] Church, printed by Parry Hall, Philadelphia
Leaf (p. 245) from The Confession of Faith, Associate Reformed Chruch, printed in New York by T. & J. Swords
Leaf 2Y2 from the Fables of Aesop, with designs on wood by Thomas Bewick, printed by E. Walker for T. Bewick and Son, Newcastle-on-Tyne
Miniature leaf (p. 35) from an edition of Horace, printed from a specially designed type, and published by A. Mesnier at Paris
Miniature leaf Q5 from a "History of Savoy," one of the "Republic Series" issued by the celebrated house of Elzevir at Leyden
Leaf (p. 387) from The NewYork Mirror and Ladies' Literary Gazette, the 7th volume. Printed by J. Seymour at New York

Leaf Q1 from Icones Veteris Testamenti, or, Illustrations of the Old Testament, from designs by Holbein. Published by William Pickering and printed by Charles Whittingham, who, with his nephew, conducted the Chiswick Press, and bears the imprint, London
Leaf QQ1 from The Book of Gems: the Poets and Artists of Great Britain, edited by S.C. Hall, with the imprint of Saunders and Otley, London
Leaf (p. 187 of The Life and Death of Richard the Third) from the historic fourth folio of Shakespeare's plays, printed at London
Leaf (p. 743) from the 3rd edition of Christopher Saur's German Bible, printed by him at Germantown, Pennsylvania
Leaf (full page engraving) from Dryden's translation of Virgil, published by Jacob Tonson at London
Leaf Bb1 from the Works of Shakespeare, printed and published by Bioren and Madan at Philadelphia
Leaf (engraving, "Time") from Collection of Stipple engravings, by C. Taylor; printed at "No. 10, near Castle Street, Holbern"
Leaf from an early 18th century illuminated Persian ms. The text consists of celebrated Persian poems and epics. Persia

Leaf (p. 127) from Constitutiones de Jurejurando, a treatise on oaths by Rabbi Moses ben Maimon, more generally known as Maimonides; edited and translated by Justus Christopher Dithmar; published by Cornelius Boutesteyn, at Leyden

Leaf (p. 89) from The Extant Works of Clement of Alexandria, with textual emendations by Friedrich Sylburgh, and a recension of the Latin translation by Daniel Heinsius; issued by Jeremiah Schrey and Heinrich Johann Meyer, at Cologne

Leaf (Yyyyyyy1, p. 639, includes some ms. marginalia) from Parliamentary Acts passed during the reign of William III of England, and printed by Charles Bill and the Executrix of Thomas Newcomb, printers to His Majesty, at London
Leaf (p. 405) from Dryden's Translation of Virgil, published by Jacob Tonson at London

Leaf (J1, p. 218) from a Latin manuscript entitled Candidum Puritatis Lilium. A treatise on logic written by one Julianus Antonius a Jaurigui in Guatemala, and "most worthily consecrated" to D. Aloysius Gonzaga
Leaf from Tables of Logarithms For All Numbers 1 to 102,100, With Other Tables. By William Gardiner, and printed in London by G. Smith
Leaf (E1) from The Sonnets of Antonmaria Salvini, issued at Florence, by the press of H.R.H. The Grand Duke of Tuscany

Leaf (Ff2, p. 227) from Lucan's Pharsalia in the original, edited, with notes, by Richard Bentley, the foremost classical scholar of his time. Printed at the private press of Horace Walpole at Strawberry Hill
Leaf (p. 61-62) from The Book of Wisdom and Lies, by Oliver Wardrop. Printed at the Kelmscott Press for Bernard Quaritch, London
Leaf from A Rackham Illustration from "Tales founded on the Plays of Shakespeare" by Charles and Mary Lamb; printed by J.M. Dent & Co. at London
Leaf (p. 65) from A Bruce Rogers Folio, a limited edition of Sir Thomas More's "Utopia," printed in New York at the Rudge Press

Leaf from The Great Paritta, a translation in Burmese on a "palm leaf book." The colophon states that this translation was completed on the 7th waxing of the month of Tawthalin of the Burmese year 1237

Leaf (p. 80) from the first printed translation in Irish of the Old Testament. The title page runs as follows: "The books of the Old Testament, translated into Irish by ... Doctor William Bedel..." Printed in London, the edition being limited to five hundred

Leaf (Xxx2, p. 263) from a Scotch law book, entitled, "Observations on the Acts of Parliament, made by King James I to King Charles II," by Sir George Mackenzie. Printed by the heir of Andrew Anderson at Edinburgh

Leaf (engraving, entitled, "Di Carlo D'Angio") from La Sicilia di Filippo Paruta, a compilation of Sicilian medals by Paruta, Secretary to the Palermitan Senate in the first half of the 17th Century, and Leonardo Agostini, Supervisor of Antiquities to the Pope. Published by Marco Maier at Lyons
Leaf (p. 5) from Anacreon, Bion and Moschus, a book of poetry in the manner of the Greek poet, Anacreon, and bearing the imprint: I.B. Bodonius, Regis Catholici Typographus Parma
Leaf (p. 191) from The Complete Measurer, by Wm. Hawney (Philomath); printed at Dublin by R. Jackson
Leaf (p. 57) from Murray's English Grammar, by Lindley Murray, printed at Boston by Robert Davies & Co.
Leaf (engraving, "Tab. CCCLVI," I.G. Pintz, sculps.) from Scheuchzer Bible engraving, an example of copper engraving from the well-known Bible
Leaf (B5, p. 15**) from Medalische Historie der Republyk Van Holland, a volume of copper engravings. Pierre Bizot was the author of this book. This leaf is from the 2nd edition printed in Amsterdam
Leaf (B2, p. 18) from an Increase Mather sermon, an American incunable leaf. This comes from the hand of the brother Cotton Mather, although there was a sister named Increase
Leaf (p. 489) from a French missal, from the press of J. Claye, Paris. This leaf is notable because the decorative borders are woodcut reproductions of a Fifteenth Century Book of Hours
Leaf (p. 159) from Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair, written by William Morris, in his famous Chaucer type, and printed by him in a limited edition at his Kelmscott Press

Leaf (plate 247, entitled, "White-breasted Nuthatch") from an Audubon lithograph, printed at New York. The second edition of the most famous set of bird prints in the world. This leaf is from The Quadrapeds and is an original engraving, as Audubon was both the artist and the engraver on stone
Leaf (plate V, by G.T. Sanford) from Natural History Lithography, by Ebenezer Emmons, M.D., published by the State of New York and printed by Charles Van Benthuysen of Albany, New York
Leaf (p. 291) from a Greek miniature, printed at Oxford by N. Bliss. This leaf is a fine example of Greek type, set to the classic Iliad
Leaf (p. 65, "Novelties for July") from Goudy's Ladies Book, printed at Philadelphia
Leaf (copper engraving) from Spieghel der Schriftkonste, a book of calligraphy, by Jan van den Velde, printed in Rotterdam
Leaf from a Persian manuscript, viz., the poem Sháhnáma of Firdausi
Leaf (p. 71) from The Luck of the Roaring Camp, by Bret Harte. The 1st illustrated edition of Harte's works, published by James R. Osgood & Co., Boston, Mass.
Leaf (p. 51, steel engraving vignette) from Gallery of English and American Poets. Printed in Philadelphia by C. Sherman & Son, and published by E.H. Butler & Co
Leaf (p. 203) from Coustumes de Touraine, a digest of laws in force in that Duchy. Printed by Estienne La Tour in the City of Tour
Leaf (C2, p. 27) from De Indiae Utriusque, Re Naturali et Medica, an illustrated work on the natural history of "Both Indies," by William Piso, printed by the Elzevirs at their Amsterdam press
Leaf (V, p. 134, with engraving) from Symbola Politica; printed by Elsiver in Amsterdam
Leaf from a Callot etching, an original and fine impression (a rendering on copperplate by intaglio) by Jacques Callot. From his second or Lorraine period

Leaf (engraving "Marci XI") from a German Bible miniature, printed in Frankfurt am Main as found in the Martin Luther translation printed by Balthasar Christoph Wustens. These perfect one inch miniatures are a rarity

Leaf from Virorum Illustrium &c., a collection of portraits of eminent monks and nuns of the Augustinian order many of whom suffered martyrdom in far distant lands. This book was printed by George Czernoch at Prague; the copper engravings are by Johann Damperviel and G. de Groos
Leaf (P1) from Ethico Politicorum, a book of emblems printed at Heidelberg by Clemens Ammon

Leaf from the Collected Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, edited by Thomas Speght and printed in London. There were two issues of Chaucer bearing this date-the first printed by Adam Islip, the second by George Bishop. This leaf is from the Islip edition
